Notes: There is a complete fracture of the distal femoral physis with lateral and proximal displacement of the epiphysis. The metaphysis is mildly irregular, and a small mineral opacitye is present on the medial cortex.

There is a displaced capital physeal fracture of the left femoral head, with mild cranial displacement of the femoral neck and remainder of the femur in relation to the head on the extended VD projection.

On the frog-leg VD projections, there is less pronounced displacement, but a step-defect between the femoral head and neck is still visible. There is disc space narrowing at L4-5 and remodeling of the adjacent endplates particularly the cranial endplate of L5. No abnormalities of the limb are identified. Most of the physes of the pelvic limbs remain at least partially open, including the intact right femoral capital physis.

Radiographs of the left hind limb reveals the presence of an aggressive lesion of the left tarsus. Lysis is noted in the distal tibia, the distal fibula, and in each of the bones comprising the tarsus. Soft tissue swelling is noted in the region of the tarsal joint. The appearance is nonspecific but a neoplastic lesion is the primary consideration. A soft tissue neoplasia of the supporting structures of the tarsus such as in synovial cell tumor is a primary consideration. Given the fact that the osseous lesions extend past the joint space, septic arthritis is not considered a possibility of this case.
There is a left capital physeal fracture. The right capital physis appears intact. No left thigh muscle atrophy is noted. The pelvis, long bones and stifles appear normal.

There is permeative osteolysis of the proximal third of the tibial diaphysis. There is a short zone of transition and mild irregular periosteal reaction. There is a short oblique fracture through the tibial diaphysis with several small associated fragments. There is mild medial and proximal displacement of the distal segment. A transverse fracture of the fibula is present at the same level.

Stifles: There is moderate intracapsular effusion in the left stifle and mild effusion in the right stifle. A small fragment is visible cranial to the femoral condyles on the lateral projection of the left stifle. On the caudocranial projection, there is a round radiolucency in the lateral condyle of the left stifle with a sclerotic rim. The right lateral femoral condyle is irregular in this region with ill-defined borders.

There is moderate effusion in both stifles with cranial displacement of the fat pad. There are radiolucent areas in both lateral femoral condyles on the lateral projections. On the craniocaudal projections, there is flattening of the lateral femoral condyles and faint radiolucency. There is only one fabella and no popliteal sesamoids in either hind limb.

There are mixed productive and destructive bone lesions in the proximal tibia, greater trochanter of the right femur, and proximal right humerus. The lesions are mainly composed of medullary sclerosis which is progressive over time. There is also increased soft tissue opacity within the stifle joint surrounding the tibial lesion.

There is a large, expansile, destructive osseous lesion of the distal right tibia with cortical destruction, most severe at the caudal and medial margins. There is also mild, irregular periosteal proliferation and soft-tissue thickening at the site.

Image Findings: Bone Lysis due to Multiple Myeloma
Bone Lysis due to Multiple Myeloma

Bone Lysis due to Multiple Myeloma

Notes: There is a soft tissue mass in the caudal aspect of the right pelvic limb along the right femur. There is a mild periosteal reaction of the caudal cortex of the right femur. The mass extends from the coxofemoral joint to the proximal aspect of the tibia.
RIGHT TIBIA/FIBULA: Changes in the right are similar to those observed in the left.

LEFT TIBIA/FIBULA: Moderate to marked, irregularly margined periosteal proliferation is present involving the metaphyses of the femur and tibia, similar to the lesions observed in the thoracic limbs. The first affected metaphyses are those of the proximal and distal tibia. Moderate soft tissue swelling is present around the proximal and distal aspects of the crus.

LEFT PELVIC LIMB: Similar to the other limbs, there is irregular linear radiolucency present in the metaphysis of the long bones. There is intracapsular effusion of the stifle joint. There is a faint, curvilinear radiopaque line through the proximal diaphysis of the medulla of the left tibia is noted.
RIGHT PELVIC LIMB: The changes in the right hind limb are similar to those in the left.

Initial images: There is a spiral fracture of the distal tibial diaphysis with slight proximal and caudal displacement. There is soft tissue swelling surrounding the fracture site. A fissure line is visible in the proximal tibia running to the epiphysis. There is a large butterfly fragment. There is also a fracture with mild comminution through the mid diaphysis of the left fibula.

2 month recheck: . On today’s exam, the surgical implants are static in location. There is a slight periapical lucency surrounding the tip of the second most distal screw. There is moderate bony callus formation surrounding the tibial fracture site and the previously described fracture lines are increasingly indistinct. There is also moderate focal bony callus formation surrounding the fibular fracture. The previously described small mineral fragment distal to the medial malleolus is unchanged.

The apophysis of the tibial tuberosity is avulsed and proximally and cranially displaced. A small sliver of bone is present distal to the apophyseal fragment. There is mild irregularity of the fracture bed. The patella is dorsally displaced. There is moderate stifle effusion.

Right stifle: There is moderately increased soft tissue opacity within the joint. The lateral femoral condyleis also flattened with a small radiolucent defect, less severe than the left. There are linear, horizontal lines visible in the medulla of the femur.

Left stifle: There is lateral luxation of the patella, and the trochlear grooves of the femur appear shallow. There is increased soft tissue effusion within the joint. On both projections, there is a radiolucent defect in the lateral condyle of the femur involving subchondral bone. Small, rounded mineral opacities are visible in the caudal aspect of the joint. There are linear, horizontal lines visible in the medulla of the femur.

On radiographs of the left pelvic limb, there is lysis of the second metatarsal bone with only a proximal remnant. The third digit, including P1-2 and the distal metatarsal bone, are also lytic. The regions surrounding the distal interphalangeal joint of P5 are also lytic. P4 appears intact. There are small fragments of soft tissue in the region of the lytic metatarsal bones. The soft tissues surrounding this region are thickened, and there is smooth periosteal reaction and sclerosis of the third and fourth metatarsal bones.

On radiographs of the left stifle, there is mild widening of the tibial apophyseal physis with a small fragment visible at the distal portion. The patellar ligament appears nomral and there is no stifle effusion present. The remainder of the pelvic limb appears normal.
Comparison views of the right stifle were obtained, and confirm the widening of the tibial apophyseal physis.
On flexed views of the left pelvic limb, the widening is exacerbated compared to the right which remains static.

Right stifle: There is marked osteolysis of the right stifle in the region of the joint capsule insertion. This is most apparent on the femoral metaphysis, tibial plateau. There is marked soft tissue swelling surrounding the joint which is displacing the patella away from the femur. The remodeling is smooth and there is no visible periosteal reaction.
Pelvic limbs: On the left fibula, there are two broad based mineral opacity nodules on the medial surface.

Left pelvic limb: There is a large, soft-tissue opacity mass in the left pelvic limb, caudal to the femur and tibia. The borders of the mass are irregularly margined. There is mottled soft tissue and fat opacity in the subcutaneous tissues of the distal pelvic limb, and the soft tissues are thickened. There is effusion in the left stifle joint with surrounding osteophyte formation. The tissues surrounding the prepuce are also thickened. No aggressive lesions are present in the femur or tibia.

Right stifle: There is mild intracapsular soft tissue opacity in the stifle joint as well as a small bony fragment in the cranial aspect. There is a lucent area of the medial femoral condyle seen on both projections and surrounded by mild sclerosis. The contour of the medial femoral condyle is irregular on a lateral projection. There is osteophytosis at the apex of the patella, fabellae, tibial plateau, and femoral epicondyles.

Left pelvic limb: There is profuse, irregular new bone formation and destruction of the distal tibia and fibula. There is new bone production cranial to the tarsus as well as caudal to the tarsus. There is a short, oblique, radiolucent line traversing the distal metaphysis and epiphysis of the tibia. Smooth periosteal reaction extends to the mid-diaphysis of the tibia with medullary sclerosis.
Original radiographs: The patellar ligament is thickened. There is no evidence of stifle joint effusion. There are no periarticular osteophytes.
Follow up radiographs: The patellar tendon is no longer clearly visualized dorsal to the stifle. The patella is displaced proximally and laterally.

Pelvis: There is suboptimal coxofemoral congruity bilaterally with femoral neck thickening and mild DJD. There is mild right thigh muscle atrophy. Right stifle: There is mild intracapsular soft tissue swelling and mild DJD. Left stifle: No abnormalities noted. Right hind paw: No abnormalities noted.

Image Findings: Mixed Bone Production and Destruction and DJD

Notes: Left stifle: Orthogonal views of the left stifle are available for interpretation. An increase in soft tissue opacity is present within the stifle joint resutling in cranial displacement of the infrapatellar fat pad and caudal displacement of the joint capsule. An increase in soft tissue opacity is also present along the medial aspect of the stifle joint. On the craniocaudal view there is a concave defect along the medial aspect of the articular margin of the medial femoral condyle. A mild degree of sclerosis surrounds this defect. On the lateral view small foci of mineralization are present superimposed over the caudal aspect of the condyle. Additional foci of mineralization are noted just adjacent to the lateral fabella (both views). These are smoothly marginated and chronic in appearance and are of unknown clinical significance. A mild degree of periarticular remodeling is noted along the medial and lateral femoral epicondyles as well as along the medial and lateral aspects of the tibial plateau. No additional abnormalities are noted.
Pelvis: lucencies are noted within the left ilium as well as the right and left femoral diaphysis. Lucencies are noted within the region of the left ischium as well.

radiographs of the right tibia reveals the presence of an area of permeative lysis in the proximal tibia. This area involve the tibial crest, the tibial metaphysis, and the proximal tibial diaphysis. There is a poor zone of transition and soft tissue swelling. There is, however, no evidence of a periosteal reaction. As is the clinical concern, there is a pathologic fracture of the cranial cortex of the tibial crest. The appearance of this lesion is consistent with an aggressive disease process. Neoplasia or osteomyelitis are the two primary considerations. In an older patient, neoplasia is the primary consideration. It should be noted that the lesion is nonspecific for tumor type. This is an atypical location for a metastatic lesion so a primary bone tumor is considered most likely. Osteogenic sarcoma is a primary consideration but fibrosarcoma or chondrosarcoma should also be considered as osteogenic sarcomas are expected to have at least some degree of a periosteal reaction. Bilaterally, digit of joint disease is present in the coxofemoral joints. The degenerative change is greater in the right and the left. Given to change is noted in the right tibia, the significance of this address change in the talus is questionable.
The coxofemoral joints are within normal limits.

Pelvic limbs: The hips appear normal. Right: THere is DJD and intracapsular soft tissue swelling affecting the right tibiotarsal joint.Additionally there is sclerosis affecting the tibial apophysis. The stifle appears normal. Left: There is severe periosteal proliferation with soft tissue swelling affecting the distal tibia.
Pelvis: radiographs of the pelvis are within normal limits.

There is an increase in soft tissue opacity within the stifle joint resulting in cranial displacement of the infrapatellar fat pad and caudal displacement of the joint capsule. A minimal degree of periarticular remodeling of the stifle joint is noted, consisting of enthesiophytes along the lateral and medial aspects of the femoral epicondyles and the margins of the fabellae. Periarticular remodeling is also present along the dorsal and medial aspects of the proximal intertarsal joint. No additional abnormalities are noted.

Pelvis: radiographs of the pelvis reveals the presence of marked, bilateral, coxofemoral degenerative joint disease. In the lateral projection of the pelvis, there is a smoothly marginated periosteal reaction dorsal to the proximal diaphysis on the right femur. This is considered to be significant and suggestive of an aggressive disorder of the proximal right femur such as a neoplastic lesion or osteomyelitis.

On the pre-operative study, there is a moderate increase in soft tissue opacity within the stifle joint resulting in cranial displacement of the infrapatellar fat pad and caudal displacement of the joint capsule. A mild increase in soft tissue opacity is also present along the medial aspect of the stifle joint. A moderate degree of periarticular remodeling is noted along all aspects of the stifle, including the apex of the patella, troclear groove, margins of the fabella and lateral/medial aspects of the femoral epicondyles and tibial plateau. The visible tarsus is within normal limits and no additional abnormalities are noted.

Left thoracic limb: The radius is absent and the ulna is hypertrophied to approximately 2-3x its normal width. The proximal radius forms a good articulation with the distal humerus. Although there is no visible proximal radius, there may be a remnant of radius fused to the proximal ulna creating a relatively normal articulation (compare to left). There is carpal varus due to the lack of radiocarpal articulation. The radiocarpal bone is absent.

Right thoracic limb: There is a small triangular bone representing a vestigial radius near the elbow. The elbow joint is less congruent compared to the left. The ulna is hypertrophied similar to the left thoracic limb. There is caudal bowing of the ulna on the lateral projection and marked carpal varus on the craniocaudal projection. The radiocarpal bone is absent.

There is a type 3 Salter-Harris fracture through the lateral distal humeral physis with mild cranial displacement of the humeral condyle in relation to the proximal humeral fracture fragment. There is moderate soft tissue swelling surrounding the distal aspect of the left humerus.

Right shoulder: On the lateral radiograph, the caudal humeral head is flattened and irregular with mild sclerosis of the subchondral bone. There are small osteophytes present on the caudal and distal glenoid as well as the inter-turburcular groove.

Left shoulder: On the lateral radiograph, there is flattening of the caudal aspect of the humeral head with a linear mineral density that is separated from the joint surface. There is mild sclerosis of the caudal humeral head. Osteophytes are present on the caudal glenoid as well as in the inter-turburcular groove. On the ventrodorsal projections, osteophytes are additionally visible on the medial and lateral aspects of the glenoid.

There is multifocal lysis of the third phalanx of the second digit of the right thoracic limb. Soft tissue swelling surrounds this region and the nail is absent. The remainder of the metacarpal bones and phalanges are normal

Right shoulder: There is proximomedial subluxation of the right shoulder joint, best seen on the caudocranial projection. Osteophytes are present on the caudal humeral head, bicipital groove, and supraglenoid tubercle.
Left shoulder: There is osteophytosis of the supraglenoid tubercle and the caudal humeral head, as well as the bicipital groove. The joint appears congruent.

Left carpus: There is marked swelling surrounding the left carpus, most pronounced on the medial aspect. There is a small osseous fragment medial to the radiocarpal bone with an associated radiolucent defect. Stressed projections were performed to assess carpal stability. No abnormal laxity was noted.
Right carpus: Comparison stressed views show no abnormal laxity.
There is stippled irregular periosteal reaction and multifocal lysis of the wing and spine of the scapula seen on the lateral projections

Elbows: There is incongruity of both elbows with widening of the humeroradial joint. The medial coronoid processes of the ulna are indistinct. There is osteophyte formation on the cranial radius and medial radius and ulna, as well as the non-articular portion of the anconeal process. Subchondral bone defects with surrounding sclerosis are present in both the left and right humeral condyles.

On a lateral radiograph of the right forelimb, there is increased mineral opacity in the medulla of the humerus and the radius. The humeral lesion is focal, and is located several centimeters proximal to the elbow. The radial lesion is more diffuse with a less well-defined zone of transition

RIGHT RADIUS/ULNA: Changes in the right antebrachium to those observed in the left. Additionally, there is moderate, irregular periosteal proliferation at the cranial and caudal aspect of the proximal humeral metaphysis with large, distinct mineral opacities at the medial and lateral aspect of the proximal aspect of the proximal humeral metaphysis, similar to the left humerus.

LEFT RADIUS/ULNA: Marked, irregularly marginated periosteal proliferation is present circumferentially involving the distal metaphyses of the radius and ulna. Faintly visible, irregular radiolucency is present in the distal ulnar metaphysis, just proximal to the physis. Smoothly marginated mineral opacities are present at the medial and lateral aspect of the proximal humeral metaphysis; a small gap is present between these mineral opacities and the margin of the humeral cortices.
RIGHT: There is an irregular subcnondral bone defect at the caudal aspect of the right humeral head, associated with minimal sclerosis.
LEFT: There are no abnormalities seen.

LEFT THORACIC LIMB: There is irregular linear lucency in the metaphysis of the proximal and distal radius as well as the distal ulna, parallel to the physis. There is mildly irregular periosteal proliferation around these regions. There is mild soft tissue swelling surrounding the elbow and carpal joints.
RIGHT THORACIC LIMB: The changes in the right thoracic limb are similar to those in the left.

Radiographs: Multiple craniocaudal and lateral projections of the left carpus are available for review as well as orthogonal projections of the right carpus with comparison. Within the left carpus the radial carpal bone appears sclerotic particularly at the medial distal aspect. There is an irregularly margined poorly defined linear lucency extending from the proximal medial to distal lateral aspect of the radial carpal bone seen on multiple projections. The distal most medial portion of the radial carpal bone adjacent to the first and second carpal bones is irregular with a curvilinear lucent portion. The remainder of the viewable skeletal structures are unremarkable. There is mild soft tissue swelling dorsal and medial to the left carpal joint.

Baseline left humerus: There is a mixed osteolytic and osteoproductive lesion in the proximal left humerus. There is an area of geographic lysis caudally, and increased opacity from the surrounding proliferative bone.

Post radiation therapy: The areas of proliferative bone surrounding the proximal humerus and extending to the soft tissues caudally have increased in opacity. There are additional areas of lysis in the proximal humerus compared to the previous exam. The area of the osteosarcoma lesion is also greater than previously seen.

Left thoracic limb: There is division of the radius and ulna at the level of the luxated elbow joint. The radius has several carpal bones and a single digit attached. The ulna has a proximal curved malformation, and there are two metacarpal bones and digits distally.

Right shoulder: There is a large soft tissue mass cranial and dorsal to the right shoulder. This is seen best when compared to the left, and is visible on the ventrodorsal flexed views. The other soft tissue and osseous structures of the thoracic limbs appear normal.

Radiographs: A single lateral projection of the left forelimb is available for review. There is geographic lysis involving the distal humerus, proximal ulna, and to a lesser degree of the proximal radius. The areas of bone loss are multifocal with relatively well circumscribed borders. The anconeal process is absent. There is a large soft tissue swelling centered around the left elbow.

On radiographs taken to evaluate a wound, there is a spicule of smooth new bone protruding from the ulna at right angles to the long axis of the bone. The lesion is several centimeters proximal to the metaphysis, and is conical in shape. There is also smooth periosteal reaction on the diaphysis of the radius. This is extending from a bone plate in the proximal radius from previous surgery (image not included).

There is geographic lysis of the proximal humeral metaphysis with irregularity of the lateral cortex on the craniocaudal projection. There is a more well-circumscribed round radiolucencly proximally which is consistent with the site of previous bone biopsy. The thoracic radiographs are within normal limits.

ELBOWS There is mild subtrochlear sclerosis of both elbows. There is a focal contour defect at the articular surface of the medial humeral condyle on the cranial caudal projection bilaterally. There is evidence of underlying subchondral sclerosis at this site. LATERAL SHOULDERS: There is a focal contour defect and radiolucency in the subchondral bone of both shoulders. In the left shoulder, there is also an ill-defined mineral body present at the caudal humeral head. The right shoulder appears to have a mineralized linear cartilage flap associated with the defect.

There are irregularly shaped defects in the caudal humeral head of both the left and right shoulders. The surrounding subchondral bone is sclerotic. There is a small, linear osseous fragment in the caudal and ventral aspect of the right shoulder joint. The remainder of the thoracic limbs appear normal.
The long bones also have areas of lysis with a short transition zone. Several lesions are surrounded by rims of sclerotic bone.
There is a 3 x 8 mm mineral opacity located just medial to the distal right ulnar metaphysis. A similar sized defect can be seen along the medial cortical margin of the ulna in this same area.

Radiographs of the right and left shoulder are available for interpretation. There is an irregularity associated with the caudal humeral head of the left humerus. The appearance is consistent with a diagnosis of proximal humeral OCD in the left limb. There is a lucent line associated with the region of the caudal humeral head of the right humerus. Although this patient is not currently demonstrating clinical symptoms of lameness of the right forelimb, this should be considered to be a significant finding and is consistent with a diagnosis of OCD in the right humerus.

1. All bones are markedly lucent with very thin cortices. 2. Both distal antebrachii have distorted conformation, although this is worse on the left forelimb where there is evidence of fractures in the distal radius and ulna with craniolateral deviation of these bones distal to the site of fracture and distorted appearance of the epiphyses. Additionally, the right manus has distorted distal metaphysis and physis of the 5th metacarpal bone, and the distal right radial physis is indistinct with malformation of the distal radial metaphysis. 3. A folding fracture is evident in the proximal right tibia with lateral deviation of the limb distal to this level.

Radiographs of both forelimbs are available for interpretation. Left elbow:There is elbow joint incongruity with narrowing to the joint space between the humeral condyle and anconeal process. There is subluxation of the humeroulnar joint. No degenerative change is noted. The distal ulnar physis appears open. There is mild radius curvus. Right elbow: Changes to the right are similar to those present on the left however the the incongruity is slightly more severe and the distal ulnar physis appears to be partially closed. Radius curvus is present similar to that on the left.

Two views of the left paw are available for interpretation. There is a rounded osseous body medial to the medial styloid process. There is soft tissue swelling with mineralization and DJD associated with the lateral aspect of MC-P5.

Left carpus: soft tissue swelling is noted in the left carpus. The soft tissue swelling is noted primarily on the lateral extent of the carpal joint and appears to represent joint effusion. A second area of soft tissue swelling is noted medial to the distal radius. This appears to represent a soft tissue cutaneous (mass?) lesion.

In the lateral projection, soft tissue swelling is noted dorsal to the carpus. There are two small fragments of bone noted dorsal to the distal row of carpal bones. These fragments of bone are smooth suggesting that they are chronic lesions such as synovial mineralization or a previous avulsion fracture.

In the lateral projection and the flexed lateral projection the joint spaces of the carpus (particularly the radiocarpal joint space) are widened consistent with subluxation of the radiocarpal joint and possibly the distal carpal joints as well.
Left shoulder: There is mixed osteolysis and osteproduction affecting the caudal aspect of the glenoid. There is mild osseous proliferation affecting the bicipital groove.

Right thoracic limb: There is luxation of the elbow joint with no articulation between the radius, ulna, and humerus. The humerus is rotated medially relative to the distal thoracic limb. The first digit originates on the medial aspect of the mid radius and ulna. Digits 2-5 are in a normal position however the second digit is shortened. The phalanges have angular malformations.

Left elbow: there is an osseous fragment adjacent to the region of the medial coronoid process in the left elbow. I'm concerned about the presence of the elbow disease in this young patient. There is also some degree of a sclerosis in the region of the medial coronoid process in the left elbow.

Right elbow: increased opacity is noted in the region of the medial coronoid process and I do not appreciate a distinct medial coronoid process in this right elbow. Degenerative change is not definitively identified at this time.
Right forelimb: There is a lytic lesion in the right humeral head. The remainder of the right forelimb appears normal.
Bilaterally, there is a triangular area of decreased opacity in the distal ulnar metaphysis consistent with a retained cartilaginous core lesion.
In the right elbow, there is a chronic ununited anconeal process with marked secondary degenerative change. Incongruity across the elbow joint is also present.

In the left elbow joint, there is very early and mild DJD characterized by early periarticular osteophyte formation ion the proximal radius and possibly the proximal ulna. This change is mild and clinical correlation is necessary to ascribe significance to this finding.
